characters: OPENS HIS EYES, SEES RICHARD NIXON
THE INTERIOR OF A FAMILY SEDAN
A GIRL IN A YELLOW DRESS
MARCH HUSTLING HOLLY ALONG THE SIDEWALK
CROSSES BETWEEN HOLLY AND JOHN BOY
THE GIANT SCREEN STARTS TO GLOW
MARCH TALKING TO A COCKTAIL WAITRESS
WE PUSH IN THROUGH A WINDOW
HEY, WHAT ARE YOU GUYS PROTESTING
GRABS THE DOOR AND YANKS IT SHUT
MARCH AT A BAR BY THE POOL
HOLLY HAS A GUN IN HER HAND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lighted HOMES dot the landscape. Clinging like stragglers to the steep canyon. Wreathed in fog. Secure. Sleepy. Above, random cars shuush by up on Mulholland.

dialogues.speaker: PUSH IN ON ONE HOME
dialogues.text: Nestled in the canyon. The back door opens, emits a brief shaft of light, as a BOY (14) in pajamas lets the dog out He shuts the door. And the CAMERA DRIFTS alongside the house. He's visible through windows, heading down the hal switching off lights as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: WE PUSH IN THROUGH A WINDOW
dialogues.text: Following behind the boy. Down a darkened hallway as he stops at one particular door... He turns the knob, ever so gently. Listens... Then -- CLICK--! The boy switches on a PEN FLASHLIGHT. Enters the room. Creeping in carefully, inching his way towards A BED. He leans down. Peers underneath. From above, SNORING. Mom, Pop. He shines the light: THERE, under the bed, surrounded by dust bunnies--

dialogues.speaker: A STACK OF PORN MAGAZINES
dialogues.text: The boy grasps one from the top. Gingerly, slides it off. Stands again. Penlight, off. Heads back out

dialogues.speaker: INTO THE HALLWAY
dialogues.text: The boy (let's call him Bobby) moves quickly now. Starts back down the hallway, examining the magazine. It's called BUSTER. And it's a clear product of its decad The cover prominently features a porn star with a notewor rack... Bold lettering proclaims her to be: SUPERSTAR MIS MOUNTAINS. Bobby smiles. We follow him into the KITCHEN. He raids the fridge. Find half a HAM SANDWICH, drops it on a plate. Eyes riveted on CENTERFOLD: MISTY in full glory-- He turns, heads toward his room... A man with a purpose. we want to know this purpose? He stops. Damn. Forgot something. Jogs back, with us in Crosses to the fridge. Opens it. Grabs a bottle of milk. Of course, forgot the milk. Where's our thinking? He stands, the kitchen window at his back, and pours hims a glass... And that's when we see something he doesn't--

dialogues.speaker: OUT THE KITCHEN WINDOW
dialogues.text: A CAR. Way in the distance. A POWDER-BLUE TRANS AM. It appears out of nowhere. Punching through the guardrail on Mulholland with a fog-muffled CRUMP-! It's almost comical. Half-obscured by Bobby's head, the c crosses our POV. Showering earth. Then it's GONE. Blink and you missed it. Window, boring a Holy shit. BOBBY, oblivious. Leaves the kitchen, actually yanks our POV away. Walks, juggling the sandwich and magazine, into the living room. Raises the glass of milk, takes a sip --

dialogues.speaker: THE WALL EXPLODES
dialogues.text: Just DISINTEGRATES. The whole damn thing. Part of the CEILING going with it, as

dialogues.speaker: THE POWDER-BLUE TRANS AM
dialogues.text: BLASTS into the house, moving impossibly fast. Showering DEBRIS. Trailing trees, brush... It hurtles across the room. DETONATES obstacles. BLOWS th splinters. Sweeps the place clean, doing 50, half on its Then, just as promptly, DEPARTS. Crash--! Sails OUT THE OPPOSITE WALL. Into the night. Just like that. CAMERA PANS TO FOLLOW -- Peering out the gaping HOLE, out and down -- Unbelievable. There it is, STILL GOING. Plunging down a HILLSIDE. Tumbling. Chewing up huge GOUTS of dirt. WHAM--! It slams to a STOP. A hundred yards down the hill Battered. Smoking... Stillness, then. Echoes, fading... BOBBY, knocked off his feet by the impact, stands shakily Stares out what used to be the back wall of his house...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BOBBY staggers downhill in his PJs. Past uprooted trees, gouged earth. Trailing in the car's WAKE -- The sound of DOGS BARKING fills the canyon now. Faintly w hear Bobby's PARENTS up above. Calling his name. Bobby stumbles. Falls. Rolls to his feet... THERE, BELOW. The car sits steaming. Roof pancaked. He forces his feet to move. Approaches the wreck as you'd approach a sleeping dragon. Cranes his neck for a look... The car is empty. And then A COUGH. BEHIND him, he spins- Stops dead. Transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: MISTY MOUNTAINS
dialogues.text: Lies twisted against a rock. Completely nude. Famous curv bruised, discolored (this is to be handled tastefully.) Bobby can't help staring. He tries to make sense of what seeing: That's Misty Mountains. That's her in the flesh. Her breath comes in hitches, gulps. Her eyes are swimming. Unfocused. Finally notices BOBBY. Fixes him with a pain-wracked star

dialogues.speaker: MISTY MOUNTAINS
dialogues.text: How... do you like my car... Big Boy. SIRENS, approaching. She convulses. Spasms once, twice. BLOOD jets from her mo She dies staring at him. The strangest moment of this kid's young life. The two of them in tableau. SIRENS, closer now. Wind, gus We hold... And then Bobby does something odd. He grips hi pajama top. Yanks it over his head. Shivers, it's cold. Steps up next to the corpse... Delicately lays the fabric across her. Covers her up. Withdraws. Stands trembling in the cold. Waiting on the sirens... CUT TO BLACK. ROLL CREDITS.  Pause, then-- HEALY (v.o) It's a different world these days. More cynical. Less innocent. You see it all around... You see it in the kids--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A roomful of sullen, vacant-eyed kids (mean age of, say 1 watching an ancient EDUCATIONAL FILM. Subject: GRAMMAR. ONSCREEN - A young boy holds up a white BEACH TOWEL:

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (ON FILM)
dialogues.text: Bart has a PLAIN towel. The word "adjective!" appears on screen, DING..! And then Bart is replaced by a little girl clutching a YELLOW TOWE

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (ON FILM)
dialogues.text: Sarah has a BRIGHT towel. DING..! Another kid, another towel. This one multi-colore

dialogues.speaker: NARRATOR, (ON FILM)
dialogues.text: Jonathan has a GAY towel. The classroom erupts in LAUGHTER... Apparently this is th funniest thing ever. One kid actually falls out of his se CAMERA settles on one YOUNG GIRL in particular, laughing with her classmates. Dark hair. Beautiful. HEALY (v.o.) They know too much. Precocious is a good word... only that doesn't get it. It's like precocious, only shittier...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: School's out. Kids exit the building. Moving in cliques. Stoners. Skaters. More Stoners. It's the 70's, after all. CAMERA FINDS our YOUNG BEAUTY as she starts home. After a moment, a fire-engine red CORVETTE pulls alongside her. Turns out she knows the guy in the car -- the MUCH OLDER in the car... They strike up a conversation as

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SOMEONE watches from a store window across the street.  He's got a kind face, this man. Late-thirties maybe. For the record? Meet JACKSON HEALY. HEALY (v.o.) Take this one. Thirteen and already she's got herself a winner. Sure, he's three times her age... But he's got money for pot. And he drives a nice car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The RED CORVETTE is parked in the driveway of one of thos modern boxes on stilts that populate the hills.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA DRIFTS
dialogues.text: To an open WINDOW. We HEAR people having sex inside: OLDER MAN (0.s.) Yeah! Who's the man, baby?! Who?! YOUNG BEAUTY (o.s.) -.. You are. You're the man. Oh, yes. You're the man! You! You!

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA FINDS HEALY
dialogues.text: Just below the window. Hidden in SHADOW. Bored, eating peanuts. Pops them one at a time... Munches. Listening: YOUNG BEAUTY (o.s.) You're the man! You're my Foxy-fox! Healy frowns: Foxy-fox..? YOUNG BEAUTY (o.s.) Foxy-fox! Foxy-fox! Healy shrugs. Picks through his handful of nuts... Whispers to himself:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but is he the man...?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BEAUTY
dialogues.text: Oh, yes baby! Yes! You're the man, baby! Ah, that's better... Healy smiles as he finds a cashew. HEALY (v.o.) Love. Grand, isn't it? (beat) I was in love once. June Miller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEALY sits across a table from a knockout BLONDE. They st into each other's eyes. A beat. Healy starts to say somet The blonde cuts him off:

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE
dialogues.text: Jack... I slept with your father. The guy at the next table does a SPIT TAKE. BACK TO SCENE - Healy dusts peanut debris from his hands. HEALY (v.o.) Marriage is buying a house for someone you hate... Remember that.

dialogues.speaker: SAME HOUSE
dialogues.text: The YOUNG BEAUTY exits. Alone. Her BICYCLE, stashed by th front door. Banana seat. Tassels on the handlebars. She g on, rides off. HEALY steps from the shadows. Stares after HEALY (v.o.) Yep, these days the world is a vulgar, unromantic place... HEALY cracks his neck. Grimaces. Slips on a pair of BRASS KNUCKLES. Starts towards the front of the house-- HEALY (v.o.) So I adjust. Healy knocks on the FRONT DOOR. The OLDER GUY answers it.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Are you the man?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: What..? Healy SLUGS him. WHAM--! SHATTERS the man's JAW-- And right then we FREEZE FRAME. On the moment of impact. The poor guy's face CONTORTED IMPOSSIBLY. Sickeningly. HEALY (v.o) I don't have a job title. I'm not in the yellow pages... But if you've got trouble with someone --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Setting up for the night's business. Healy sits in a boot the back of the club. An older man sits across from him.  HEALY (v.o.) -- Someone's threatening you, someone's messing around with your underage daughter. Whatever -- The older man gives Healy an ENVELOPE. Shakes his hand. L HEALY (v.o.) -- You might ask around for me: Jackson Healy's the name... When business is good, I'm easy to find. When it isn't--?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crammed to overflowing with weary travelers. The color ORANGE at the apparent height of its popularity. Healy sits by himself in the first row. A slim metal BRIEFCASE rests on the seat by his side. HEALY (v.o.) , -- Means I'm traveling... The 1° and 14° of every month. Healy reaches into the front pocket of his jacket, takes a pack of PARLIAMENTS. Lights up, one handed. Never taking his other hand off the briefcase. HEALY (v.o.) LA to New York. Drop off and pick up. No questions asked. Not something I'm proud of... But it's work. A stewardess approaches Healy--

dialogues.speaker: STEWARDESS
dialogues.text: Sir..? I'm sorry, but if you'd like to smoke you'll have to move to the smoking section of the plane. Healy follows her finger. On the floor, a yellow LINE. Be that, a bunch of people smoking. Healy gets up -- Moves FIVE WHOLE FEET. Sits. Ah. Now it's cool to smoke. Joins his fellow smokers, puffing away. Smoke BILLOWS throughout the plane... A BABY coughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The city of Los Angeles laid out as far as the eye can se Which isn't that far, really. SMOG obscures most of the v TWO CARS are parked up here. Healy's Chevelle, and a Ford  Healy leans against the Ford. HEALY (v.o.) Sometimes I feel okay about things. Not often. Scotty, my AA sponsor, keeps trying to get me to quit this kind of work. Inside the Ford is a WOMAN. Dirty blonde hair. Young. Healy a slip of PINK, COW-SHAPED NOTEPAPER:

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I think there's two of ‘em... I just got the name and description for one. They've been talking to all my friends, asking where I live. I'm scared. Healy studies the slip of paper. Pockets it. The woman hands him an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: You'll take care of ‘em?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Consider it done. The girl offers Healy a fragile smile.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Thank you... I feel better already. You... You make me feel safe.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: (smiles) That's my job. Healy starts to leave, counting the money in the envelope Then stops. Turns back. Leans in the window:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Um, you're short.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I'm... What?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: You're twenty bucks short.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm sorry... Here, ummm... She fishes through her purse for some cash. Finds two ten

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Sorry, here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The FORD drives off. Taillights, receding. Healy watches HEALY (v.o.) Truth is, I've been thinking about what Scotty said... I could try for an investigators' license. Become a detective, you know..? Those guys help people. (beat) Maybe then I'd feel good in the morning. CUT TO BLACK. Pause. Then--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A HAND dangles limply from the edge of a PORCELAIN TUB. WIDEN to reveal a tousled-looking MAN, 40-ish. FULLY DRESSED, immersed in water up to his neck. Dead asleep... Meet HOLLAND MARCH. Somewhere in the house a PHONE starts to RING. Slowly, March's EYES open. He sits up, sloshing water. Winces. Puts a hand to his throbbing temple. Stops, frown There's something WRITTEN on the palm of his hand. With a permanent marker, in an unmistakably feminine scri

dialogues.speaker: YOU WILL NEVER BE HAPPY
dialogues.text: March just stares at it: How did that get there..? The ph still RINGING. March ignores it. An answering machine pic ANSWERING MACHINE (0.s.) You have reached March Investigations. This machine records messages. Wait for the tone, and speak clearly. A BEEP, followed by: YOUNG GIRL'S VOICE (HOLLY) (o.s.) This is your daughter speaking. Thursday, as you may remember, is my birthday. Please give accordingly -- March waves a hand at no one in particular.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, yeah... YOUNG GIRL'S VOICE (HOLLY) (o.s.) Also, I hope you didn't forget that you're supposed to be working today --  10 March blinks. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Oh, shi-- He's already leaping out of the tub. Over this we HEAR: MARCH (v.o.) What with the world coming to an end, you'd think people would, you know, band together or something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March in a beat-up CONVERTIBLE. Stuck in a GAS LINE. Cars HONKING as March inches towards the ARCO STATION. MARCH (v.o.) Nossir. People are still mean and petty and unforgiving... which is good, ‘cuz otherwise I'd be out of a job. Up at the pumps, a FIGHT breaks out. March ignores it... Peruses the day's newspaper. A featured headline:

dialogues.speaker: BRAZIL'S 'KILLER BEE' RAMPAGE CONTINUES
dialogues.text: He takes out a PORTABLE ELECTRIC RAZOR the size of a BRIC Starts shaving. The glamorous life of a detective. MARCH (v.o.) They implemented a no-fault divorce here couple of years back. That screwed things up... Lotta private cops folded. (beat) Not me. I got this guy, runs security at a local retirement park, he kicks a few cases my way -- slam dunks, most of ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: FLASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: March, in the living room, talking to an OLD LADY. He writes in a notebook as she relates her problem:

dialogues.speaker: OLD LADY
dialogues.text: It's my husband. Fred is his name. He's gone missing.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (professional concern) Missing..? I see.  11

dialogues.speaker: OLD LADY
dialogues.text: I'm terribly worried... Fred's just never been gone for this long. March nods, writes... Then spots something out of the cor of his eye: There's an URN over the fireplace. March squints at the PLAQUE affixed to it: FRED MILLER -- A devoted and loving husband. March frowns.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Um, Mrs. Miller... Your husband Fred..? Exactly how long has he been missing?

dialogues.speaker: OLD LADY
dialogues.text: Oh, let's see... (furrows her brow) Probably since the funeral. March nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I see... I see... (puts away notebook) Well, I can start today if you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March slouches in his car. Watches through the window of Hollywood SEX SHOP. A couple debates which dildo to buy. man holds up several; the woman shakes her head. MARCH (v.o.) Lean pickings, but I hang in... Maybe I'm a fighter. Maybe someday people will notice. Maybe the flying pigs will tell them. MARCH snaps pictures of the couple. The woman shakes her head, still obstinate --

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (sighs) Honey, you're not gonna find one with a breadmaker in it, just buy the fucking thing. He snaps another photo.  12 MARCH (v.o.) In the meantime, I take whatever's out there. It's bottom feeding, sure. But at least you're getting fed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March is talking to the guy behind the counter:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: ... She's blonde, about yea high..? Might be from the neighborhood. Name's Amelia. The worker shakes his head. March turns, and we follow him OUT OF THE SHOP. He stands the sidewalk out here, stares down the street at a long l other establishments-- MARCH (v.o.) It ain't rocket science. It's grunt work.

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Literally going store to store. Asking questions at the Quick-e-Mart. At a fast food join Talking to a VALET. Talking to a NUDE DANCER, Bent-double peeking through her knees... She shakes her head, no. MARCH (v.o) You ask questions. Pound the pavement. Chances are something's gonna pop--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCH'S CONVERTIBLE pulls to the curb. He gets out, notic his hand: YOU WILL NEVER BE HAPPY. Faded, but still there Scowls at it. Looks down the row of seamy BARS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCH talking to the bartender. Looking worn out.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: I think I remember her. Amelia, right? She was in three, four nights ago. Drank bourbon martinis. March perks up instantly:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: That's disgusting. Pay with a credit card, by any chance?  13

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: As in, am I gonna pull the receipts for you? Fat fucking chance. March offers up a folded $10 bill.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: That's very pretty.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I made it myself.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: Yeah? I made this. He produces a carved wooden BAT from under the bar. CUT T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Shadowy. Across the alley, we see the same bartende LOCKING UP. He pockets the keys. Heads off... MARCH (v.o.) Look, I'm not saying it's easy. I'm not saying you don't gotta think on your feet. Bend a few rules, maybe. Pan to REVEAL MARCH, behind a dumpster. Dark sweater, bla cloth cap. He takes a RAG, proceeds to wrap his KNUCKLES.

dialogues.speaker: BACK DOOR OF CLUB
dialogues.text: March sidles up, whistling. Glances both ways. MARCH (v.o) But it's worth it. As long as you get the results-- He braces himself. PUNCHES THROUGH the glass pane.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Ow! Shit! He pulls his hand back out. His wrist is BLEEDING. Fuck. He puts pressure on it. Red SEEPS through his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Ow, OW, Ow. Damn, that's a lot of blood. He takes the RAG from his knuckles, tries to cover the wound... The rag turns red instantly. Starts dripping.  14

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Woah. Ow. Woah. Lots of blood. Lots of blood. Okay. Okay. March takes a few steps back, stumbles. Suddenly dizzy no Goddamn, that's a lot of blood. He shifts his grip -- and a literal STREAM OF BLOOD spews preposterously. Straight up into the air. He teeters ina tight little circle. Blood squirting everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Okay. Ow. Wait, wait. Okay. Okay. His eyes start to flutter now as we SLAM-CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: BACK OF AMBULANCE
dialogues.text: Blasting through traffic, siren WAILING. March's face, CHALK-WHITE. Head lolling. A MEDIC hunches over him--

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: I need two units of whole blood! Shit! BP dropping! Christ, we're LOSING HIM--! The ambulance careens across lanes. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The night quiet. Serene. A HOSPITAL NUN wheels a bandaged March outside, to a waiting TAXI. Helps him stand.

dialogues.speaker: NUN
dialogues.text: Tell me, are you willing to find God?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (doped up) No can do... I'm already looking for Amelia. He staggers to the cab, climbs in. MARCH (v.o.) Bottom line, I get by. I make some money. I live my life. I'm happy...

dialogues.speaker: TIME-CUT
dialogues.text: A placid, narcotized MARCH in back. MARCH (v.o.) Except, you know, for all the stuff I'm not happy about... But it's best not to think about that.  15 The taillights recede into the gleaming distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A thick crust of smog hangs in the air. The sun still bla

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The Air Quality Management District today issued a stage two smog alert for most of the Los Angeles basin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small place. Situated just above "The Comedy Store on Sunset. Clean. Spartan. It looks like a monk lives her Healy lies in bed, atop rumpled sheets. Stares at the cei The newscast continues on the TV nearby:

dialogues.speaker: NEWSCASTER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The AQMD cautions residents not to engage in any unnecessary exercise until after 6 pm tonight... Healy checks the time: 4:21 PM. Sighs. Sits up. NEWSCASTER (v.o.) Infamous adult film star Misty Mountains was pronounced dead early yesterday morning, after driving her car off a Canyon road. Drugs may have played a-- Healy shuts the TV off. TIME CUT: HEALY BUTTONING HIS DRESS SHIRT. He stops to sprinkle fish-food into a saltwater aquarium. On his desk, a daily "tear-off" CALENDAR. Your word for t day! He tears off yesterday's page. Reveals today's word: Equanimity \e-qua-nim-i-ty\, noun: The quality of being c and even-tempered; composure.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: She accepted their problems with grace and he with equanimity. Healy smiles, pleased with himself. Finishes with his shi Grabs his coat, exits the room... SLAM! In the foreground we see something he forgot -- Something shiny. His BRASS KNUCKLES.  16

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy, on the way somewhere. Cruising up Laurel Canyon. As he nears a construction area -- POV HEALY: He sees a cute YOUNG GIRL. 14, maybe 15 years old-- Sees her snake beneath a chain-link fence. Once inside, she stands. Dusts herself off. Paces off 10 steps across the scorched, barren ground. 6 steps over, 3 back -- like following a treasure map. Healy, puzzled. This is really very odd behavior. She finds a specific spot. SITS. Composed. Takes out a BO Starts to read aloud. We have no idea why she's doing thi ANGLE ON HEALY, GOING BY... His gaze lingers a moment, curious. Then he turns the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEALY pulls up. Takes a slip of familiar NOTEPAD PAPER ou his pocket. It's PINK. And shaped like a COW. Checks it-- Then gets out of the car, whistling a tune. He crosses to slightly run down 50's-modern HOUSE. Patting his coat poc as he goes, looking for something: His brass knuckles. Gone. Shit. He shrugs it off. KNOCKS.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Just a minute..! Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Messenger service. Holland March home..? The door opens -- revealing none other than HOLLAND MARCH Distracted, scratching at the bandage on his wrist--

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Hi. Healy SLUGS MARCH full in the face. March drops as though pole-axed. Healy steps past him. Inside. Shaking his hand in pain... Shuts the door. Looms over March. Poised like a dancer:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Mr. March, we're gonna play a game.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: This is a mistake, you got the --OOOFF--!  17

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: It's called, "Shut up, unless you're me."

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (gasping) I... I LOVE that game. Healy spots March's WALLET on a nearby counter. SLUGS him again for good measure, then crosses -- begins idly flipp through the wallet. Stops. Whistles low:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: You're a private investigator? MARCH manages to sit up. Props himself against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Look... There's 30 bucks there. Take it.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I told you, I'm a messenger. (looks around) You afford this on a P.I.'s salary?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: At night I'm a superhero. What's the message? Healy kneels down next to March--

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Stop. Looking. For Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Fine. Hey. 'Nuff said. Put a fork in me. I'm done. Don't really put a fork in me.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: (stands) That's fine, Mr. March. Amelia will be happy to hear you got the message. Almost done. Last thing..?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: You wanna know who hired me to find her.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Bingo. Now, we can do this the easy way--

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Her name's Glenn.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Or we can do this the hard way--  18

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: My client's name is Lily Glenn. She's an old woman. Thinks Amelia might be her niece... Hired me on Tuesday. Healy stops, momentarily thrown. March spits blood.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Anything else..?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: You just gave up your client.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Well, I made a discretionary revelation--

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: No, you gave her up, just like that. Some poor old woman pays you good money and that's how you treat her..? March just shrugs. Supports himself on a coffee table... Stands. Slowly, painfully. Covertly slipping one hand int an OVERTURNED COOKIE JAR-- Comes up with a .38 SPECIAL. Spins toward Healy... Only Healy isn't where he was, he's dropped, he's on the ground, foot lashing out -- KICKING THE COFFEE TABLE. -- WHAM! -- the whole damn thing comes up from the ground SLAMS MARCH in the face. Knocks him back on his ass. Healy is on him in a flash. Grabs the gun. Dumps the shel Tosses it... Says, sadness in his voice:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry you didn't get the message.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I get it now. I dig. I get it. Healy grabs March, wrenches his bandaged arm up behind hi back. Pins him against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Ow. Watch it there! I'm injured!

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Listen, when you talk to your doctor, tell him you've got a spiral fracture of the right humerus... Got that?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Wait, wait... Jesus, man, STOP!  19

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Deep breath. Healy twists March's arm PAST THE BREAKING POINT -- CRACK March screams as we SLAM-CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy comes out the front door. A YOUNG GIRL, carrying a grocery bag, is headed the opposite way, swigging a drink It's the same girl he saw in the FENCED-OFF LOT earlier. This, we will come to realize, is March's daughter HOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Hi. Want a Yoo-Hoo?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: A Yoo-Hoo..? Man, I haven't had one of those in about 10 years.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Knock yourself out. (hands him one) You a friend of my Dad's?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Business associate. He's inside. Resting. (vigorously shaking the bottle) Didn't I see you crawling around an empty lot a few blocks over..?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: ... Maybe... I read there sometimes. Healy nods. Takes a swig of his drink. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: "It's me-he for yoo-hoo!" (nods again, a beat) Well... Thanks. The girl waves. Walks up to the house. Healy gets into hi Takes another sip of Yoo-Hoo. Smiles. Drives off. CUT TO: A WHOLE DAMN CASE OF YOO-HOO. CLINK-ING as --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy lugs it down the sidewalk on Sunset. Pushes through small crowd of people waiting outside a CLUB.  20

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy night. A BAD STAND-UP holds forth on the lighted sta

dialogues.speaker: RONNIE THE COMIC
dialogues.text: So you heard about this lawsuit..? L.A. is suing the automakers over the catalytic converter. (beat) Thing is, I don't see what all the fuss is about... I installed one on my car, nothing happened... Except, well, I turned into a Catholic. But that's it. The laughter is not deafening. Healy wrestles the Yoo-Hoos through an UNMARKED DOOR at t back of the club. Starts up a FLIGHT OF STAIRS -- Someone enters behind him. Healy looks back: TWO MEN. One's older, with horn-rimmed glasses and a brus cut. The other's in his twenties, feathered hair and gold chains. Back in the day, Richard Lynch would have played this guy. Don't know who that is? Shame on you.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Sorry, this area is private. Gold Chain ignores this. Starts up toward Healy. The Olde Guy closes the door at the base of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: GOLD CHAIN
dialogues.text: Wow. You got, like, an apartment up here?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Guys, if you're looking for a bathroom--

dialogues.speaker: GOLD CHAIN
dialogues.text: Nice try. We're looking for Amelia. A BLUR OF SILVER. GOLD CHAIN has a STEEL BATON. Healy can't react. Hands fu -- WHACK--! Down he goes. Yoo-hoo's SMASHING as we CUT TO

dialogues.speaker: AN OLD WOMAN'S FACE, DISTRAUGHT
dialogues.text: This is Lily Glenn. And she looks like she's about to cry

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCH walks past camera. His right arm is in a CAST now.  21

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Mrs. Glenn, let's be reasonable; this is a high profile case, your niece was a famous, um... actress. The head medical examiner himself ID'd the body--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GLENN
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, I SAW her, Mr. March. I didn't imagine it. I saw my Misty alive. (exasperated) I... I thought you said you found her...

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: No... I said I was tracking the girl you saw; doesn't mean it's your niece.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GLENN
dialogues.text: Why won't anyone believe me?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Mrs. Glenn, you were upset. You were at your dead niece's house, all those painful memories -- you just made a mistake, could happen to anybo--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GLENN
dialogues.text: I'm telling you, it was Misty. There was no mistake... I saw her through the front window--

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Yes, you said--

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GLENN
dialogues.text: --clear as day. She was wearing a blue pinstriped jacket. She was writing something... Then she came out and drove off before I could get her attention. (points) This was TWO DAYS after the accident! AFTER they said she went off that cliff! A pause. March takes a deep breath... Then:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Mrs. Glenn, Misty Mountains is dead... She died in that accident... I never should have taken your money in the first place. The old woman starts to cry. Chin set in feeble determination:  22

dialogues.speaker: MRS. GLENN
dialogues.text: Even if it's for nothing... Even if this Amelia girl isn't my niece... I don't have anything else, do you understand..? Please, Mr. March -- please -- will you keep looking for her? For me? March sighs... Considering. Then looks the old lady directly in the eye and says:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March climbs in the passenger side. Slams the door. A pau Holly sits in the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Holly... Am I a bad person? Holly picks at her nails, distracted.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: ... Yeah, pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (nods, then) Drive. Get me out of here. Holly puts it in gear.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Did you solve the case, dad?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: ... Sure. Yeah. Case closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM--! Healy smacks against a wall. Then crumples as GOLD CHAIN enters frame. Looms over him. In the background OLDER GUY is tossing the place. Emptyin drawers. Throwing stuff... Gold Chain kneels next to Heal

dialogues.speaker: GOLD CHAIN
dialogues.text: Okay, sport, I'm asking you again... Where is Amelia? Healy makes himself sit up. He looks resigned, weary. He spots a pack cigarettes amongst the nearby debris. Grabs as a wave of LAUGHTER wafts up from the club below.  23

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: .».. Told you... I just don't know anyone named Amelia... I-- Gold Chain KICKS Healy in the gut, WHAM--! No warning. Fo sideways, retching. More LAUGHTER from the club below. Healy straightens again. In pain.

dialogues.speaker: GOLD CHAIN
dialogues.text: You don't talk, we're gonna have to start breaking your fingers. You understand.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I understand. OLDER GUY calls out:

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GUY
dialogues.text: Got some kind of hidden cabinet here! GOLD CHAIN turns, crosses the room. Starts pounding on th cabinet. Breaks it open. Inside is a heavy canvas BAG.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: UM, YOU DON'T WANNA OPEN THAT... That's not mine. My friend wanted me to hold it for him... Trust me, don't-- GOLD CHAIN ignores Healy, rips the bag open-- AN EXPLOSION OF BLUE PAINT. Just like one of those charges they hide with bank money. Turns Gold Chain's face an impossible, shocking BLUE -- At which point, through the floor, comes the BIGGEST BUZZ YET of LAUGHTER... Like a sitcom soundtrack.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: That's, um... that's not gonna come off. GOLD CHAIN snarls. Savagely wipes his face on towels. Crosses to the AQUARIUM, dips his face, scrubs--

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Tried to tell you. Gold Chain stops. His still-blue face dripping wet.

dialogues.speaker: GOLD CHAIN
dialogues.text: You tried to tell me..? He reaches in the tank, grabs a TROPICAL FISH -- FLINGS I  24 It SMACKS the wall wetly. Next to Healy.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Come on, the fish...? Don't do that. No dice. The guy just sneers, groping for another fish. Healy appeals to the older dude:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Can you please tell this guy to act like a professional? Older Guy just SHRUGS as Gold Chain gets hold of a yellow striped number. Tosses it, squirming, into Healy's lap.

dialogues.speaker: GOLD CHAIN
dialogues.text: You're gonna eat that, bastard. Do it!!

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: This isn't gonna help you... Do you get that? This is silly and unprofessional--

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: No. Gold Chain draws an AUTOMATIC. Lets it dangle at his side

dialogues.speaker: GOLD CHAIN
dialogues.text: ... Stand up. Healy sighs. Gets to his feet. It's slow going. He's in p Stands in the middle of the room... Arms held loosely.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Stop and think. Is this why you came here tonight? To make me eat fish? To shoot me? Healy locks eyes with the kid. Gone is any trace of resignation. Of passivity. He suddenly looks... hard.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: You could have come in here. Beat up on me. Trashed the place. I wouldn't have cared. It's what I expected. (shakes his head) But you didn't do that. Instead you gotta piss me off. Make an enemy. Even if I did know something, there's no way I'd give it up to you. You're a moron. (pause) Also, Slick, blue ain't your color.  25 GOLD CHAIN RAISES THE GUN AND FIRES. Healy's already in motion..! The bullet goes wide. Past Healy's shoulder, keeps going --

dialogues.speaker: OUT THE OPEN WINDOW
dialogues.text: Hits a WOMAN in the APARTMENT across the street. Her half-open window SHATTERS, pop--! Arm wound. She goes down with a YELP. Drops from sight. The OLDER GUY knocks the GUN aside.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GUY
dialogues.text: You stupid son of a bitch! VOICES, now, from across the way. SHRIEKING. Healy, a BLUR. Dives into the BEDROOM. Hits, flat. Sweeps a SHOTGUN from behind the bed. SPINS, barrel up -- Front door, open. Still swinging... Visitors, gone. CUT T

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Googie architecture gleams in the bright morning sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A party for Holly in progress. MARCH stands at the counte surrounded by a pack of howling YOUNG GIRLS, all CALLING their shoe sizes. He raises a hand:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, EASY. Christ Jesus, one at a time, huh? THANK you. Janet, size..?

dialogues.speaker: JANET
dialogues.text: You took the Lord's name in vain.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: No, I didn't, I found it useful... Cindy, you a six..?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Except every ball goes straight in the gutter. Squeals, giggles..!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCH, in a closed stall. On the pot. Reading TIME MAGAZI The cover story's about GLOBAL COOLING.  26 Arm, still bugging him. He fishes out a cigarette, lights Hears the bathroom door open. Clopping FOOTSTEPS. Looks d ALLIGATOR BOOTS. Outside. A hand TAPS politely:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I'm in here. HEALY (0.s.) It's me, Mr. March. I intend you no harm. You're safe. Say "yes" if you understand.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE STALL
dialogues.text: Stands JACKSON HEALY. Calm, posture seemingly casual. He waits... Then, slowly, the stall door swings wide--

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: ~.. Yes. Reveals MARCH, still on the throne. Holding the door open with his bad hand. The other's got a GUN trained on Healy

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: How stupid do you think I am? Huh..? I got a permit to carry, dumbass, and since your little "visit" yesterday this baby stays right here, right where I can-- As he goes to pat his holster, the STALL DOOR starts to swing closed, he quickly has to BANG it back open. He loo ridiculous. The cigarette falls from his lips, burns his leg. He swears --

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: ... Need any help?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Just stay right there, you mother. March reaches for his pants, the STALL DOOR swings shut again. He BANGS it open -- he can't hold his gun, and the door, and pull his pants up.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: ... I got this.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: You mind if I look away..? March shifts. Tentatively rises up... Gives up. Sits agai

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: All right, this is pissing me off... What do you want?  27 Healy takes a deep breath, looks a little embarrassed:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I, uh... I need you to find Amelia for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March is wary. Watchful. Healy attacks a slice of pecan p with gusto, seemingly unruffled.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: ++. SO you think these guys want to... hurt this chick Amelia?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Sure... After they're done killing her.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Any way to warn her?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I can't reach her. I been trying.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I don't get it. Why do you care? What's in it for you? A pause. Healy chews, swallows... Then:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I don't want to have to move. March looks thoroughly perplexed. Healy shrugs:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Look, it doesn't matter. Healy drops a wad of bills on the table.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Two days in advance. That's $400. Plus whatever the old lady's giving you --

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Old lady, fuck you, old lady, you broke my arm, I quit, remember?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: So call her up, get back on the case. Get paid twice. March dry-washes his face with his hands.  28

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Help me find Amelia. You were looking for her, right..?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: .«.. Yes and no.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Excuse me? March leans back in his chair, sighs.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Last week, the old broad hired me to find her niece -- Misty Mountains.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Misty Moun-- (stops, frowning) The dead chick? The porno chick--?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Yeah. That one. (leans forward) Two days after the crash, Auntie Lily went to clean out her niece's place... Spotted Misty inside her house, through the front window. Alive and well. Then saw her drive away.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I checked it out anyway... Talked to the guard at the front gate, turns out there was a girl there that evening --

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Amelia. The old lady saw Amelia. March makes a "bingo" gesture.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Guard confirmed it. Keeps notes of all cars, in and out. I ran the plate, got her name --

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: And..? March affects disinterest. Casually holds up three finger  29

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Three. (frowns ) Three what?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Three days, in advance. If you want the rest.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: $600..? That's fucking robbery.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I only got $400.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Banks are still open, you can hold one up if you hurry. From behind him comes a "bud-dum-BAH-!" He turns, startle And sees HOLLY there. Perched on the edge of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Holly, what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Giving you a rim job.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Whatever. (plops down beside him) Hey, can we go one more game, before-- She sees Healy. Stops, blinks...

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: ... You're the guy that beat up my dad.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: It's okay. He won't hurt me, he only did it for money. He's a nice guy... aren't you, slick? Healy manages a lame smile. Holly stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You beat people up... and charge money?  30

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Wow. No way... So, um... How much would you charge to beat up my friend Janet?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: How much you got?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Okay, discussion over.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey, is that apple pie? She reaches over and grabs March's plate. Starts eating. Bouncing a little in her seat. Happy as a clam.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Two days. That's all I got. March makes a decision:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Four hundred. Two days. We find her sooner, I keep the money.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: That's good. He scoops up the money, checks his watch:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Because I already know where she is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids playing on swings. Blankets with family picnics. Nearby, littered across the grass: More than A HUNDRED PEOPLE. Sprawled on the ground. Arms, legs akimbo. Each one weari a GAS MASK, lying perfectly still... This is a "Die-in." They're pretending to be dead as a form of protest. Hand painted signs proclaim: FOR THE BIRDS! To one side, a few spectators. Smoking. Pointing. Looking bewildered. Whatever...  31 MARCH and HEALY appear at the edge of the gathering.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (nods at the protesters) There you go. Thank you and goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Wait. What do you mean, there I go..?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: This is Amelia's protest group. She's in there somewhere. So. Have at it-- March turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Hold on -- how do you know she's actually in there?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I told you, it's her protest group. She started it. Which was the hot tip I got yesterday just before you broke my arm.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Okay, but she's holed up somewhere, hiding, right? What makes you think she's gonna be here, if--

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Of course she's gonna be here. It's her protest group.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Stop saying that.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (put-—upon) You know what? Watch this. He turns. Loudly addresses the crowd of protesters:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: EXCUSE ME! HI! We're looking for Amelia. No response -- everybody still pretending to be dead.

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: (nothing)

dialogues.speaker: ANYONE HERE KNOW AMELIA
dialogues.text: Finally, from amongst the "dead" comes a mask-muffled VOI  32 VOICE (0.s.) We can't talk to you! March squints, searching for the source of the voice.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: What? Who said that? VOICE (0.s.) We can't talk to you! We're dead!

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, okay, I get it. Real clever... But this is a serious matter here. VOICE (0.s.) So is this, we've all been killed.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Look, pal-- VOICE (0.s.) Fuck you, we're dead! One of the smoking onlookers turns to March, offers helpf

dialogues.speaker: SMOKER
dialogues.text: They can't talk to you, man. They're dead.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Thanks. That's helpful. The smoker smiles, nods: no problem. HEALY turns to the h

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: What are these assholes protesting anyway..?

dialogues.speaker: SMOKER
dialogues.text: I dunno... (smokes more, then)

dialogues.speaker: HEY, WHAT ARE YOU GUYS PROTESTING
dialogues.text: Pause, then: VOICE #2 (0o.s.) The air.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: You're protesting the air..? VOICE #2 (o.s.) The pollution. The birds can't breathe.  33

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: So you all died because of the pollution? VOICE #2 (0o.s.) Right.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: What about the gas masks? I mean, wouldn't that have saved you? Long pause... no one answering this one. VOICE #3 (0.s.) ... They didn't work. March, his plan in tatters. Steps into the crowd:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Can we get back to Amelia here-- He steps on some guy's hand:

dialogues.speaker: DEAD GUY
dialogues.text: Ouch, fucker!

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Sorry. (addressing everyone)

dialogues.speaker: SPEAK WITH YOU...
dialogues.text: A new voice cuts in now, this one from behind March somew VOICE #4 (0.s.) Hey. Dickhead. She's not here.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Of course she's here. This is her protest group. VOICE #4 (0.s.) So..?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: So that means she's here. VOICE #4 (0.s.) Well, she isn't.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Yes, she is. VOICE #4 (0.s.) No, she isn't.  34 March getting pissed now. Glances back at Healy for help. Healy just shrugs: What do you want me to do..? Now another dead protester starts talking:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: She's not here because of her boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (turning towards the new voice) Her boyfriend..? Why? VOICE #5 (0.s.) "Cuz he died. Really died. Three days ago.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: He died..? So then, where's Amelia..? VOICE #5 (0.s.) We can't help you. We're dead. March stares up into the sky, exasperated:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Okay. Which one of you assholes wants to make twenty bucks..?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: March driving. Healy in the passenger seat. One of the PROTESTERS sits in back. Brown hair, about five foot five Gas Mask pushed back on his head. His name is Chet.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Up here, Chet..?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Yeah. Make a left here. March turns left. Pulls up to the curb. They all climb ou They're standing in front of BLACKENED HUSK that was once COZY BUNGALOW... It's been burned to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: What the fuck is this..?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: That's Dean's house. Amelia's boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: That's not a house, Chet.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I told you, he burned to death--  35

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: But you didn't tell us the house burned to death.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: So..?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: So now we can't search it.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Oh. (beat) Maybe you can search the burned part. March sighs. This is not going well.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I thought you knew Amelia.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I mostly knew her through Dean... He kept talking about some film they were making.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Film?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: He was a filmmaker. Experimental films. That's how we became friends. 'Cuz I'm kinda in the business myself.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: I'm a projectionist.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: Anyway, Dean stored all his stuff here. Had a bunch of old film stock. That's what caused the fire. Went up, POOF! -- (nods ) His life's work and his life. Gone... Makes you think, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Not really. March spots a kid, 14 or so, long hair. Riding his bike j up the street. He motions to him:  36

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Hey, kid! Come here! The kid rides up. Eyes March with adolescent defiance:

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: You know the guy that lived here?

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: Maybe... What's it to ya?

dialogues.speaker: CHET
dialogues.text: He'll give you 20 bucks if you answer.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Wait, I didn't say that.

dialogues.speaker: KID
dialogues.text: 20 bucks, man. Or you can blow. March takes a deep, deep breath. Fishes a twenty out of h pocket. Hands it to the kid.

dialogues.speaker: KID

dialogues.text: I think he's still in sight. They BOOK. Back up the hill. Hit a set of wooden STEPS an keep right on climbing. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE AMAZON leads Holly past the valet station. Down the street to a waiting LIMO. Engine idling.

dialogues.speaker: AMAZON
dialogues.text: Hop in back, sweetie. Holly swallows hard. Climbs in, heart thudding. There is man seated back here. Face turned, looking out the window The Amazon leans in after Holly, says:

dialogues.speaker: AMAZON
dialogues.text: This one says she's Amelia's sister. Then pulls back out, SLAMMING THE DOOR.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Is that a fact? He turns to look at Holly -- his face, a scrubbed but no less vivid shade of BLUE...

dialogues.speaker: BLUE FACE
dialogues.text: Good times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With HEALY and MARCH, as they retreat up OUTSIDE STAIRS. Pushing through people, shoving them aside. March reaches a wooden LANDING: Deck, hot tub. Lunges for the NEXT set of stairs. Healy appears, close on his heels. Turns towards the stai accidentally SLAMS into a big guy. Starts to apologize -- FREEZES. Dead stop. We recognize the BYSTANDER. It's OLDER GUY. Blue-Face's partner. Big as life. Their eyes lock.... They launch. NO HESITATION. March, everyone else, forgott  55 Older Guy's .38, clearing leather -- Healy KICKS OUT--! Sends it sailing. It lands in the HOT TUB. Older Guy counters: PULLS A SWITCHBLADE. Lunges. PANDEMONIUM. The deck clears rapidly. People SCREAMING. Running every which way, surging up the stairs and meanwh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLLY pressed back up against the door of the limo. Feeli behind her for the door handle.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: - No thanks. I think we must be talking about a different Amelia. Blue Face inching towards her. Voice deadly calm:

dialogues.speaker: BLUE-FACE
dialogues.text: Really..? How can you be sure? Why don't you describe your sister for-- Suddenly he stops. Breaks off mid-sentence, staring past out the window. Holly darts a look herself, sees--

dialogues.speaker: A GIRL IN A YELLOW DRESS
dialogues.text: Bolts out of the front door of Shattuck's house. Frantic. Trailing a backpack. Accosting the VALET. YELLING:

dialogues.speaker: YELLOW DRESS
dialogues.text: I need my keys. Now. My keys, HURRY--! Her words, clearly audible. BLUE FACE flicks a glance at the seat across from him. Holly, following his gaze again: A FADED PHOTOGRAPH sits there. It's a shot of AMELIA. The woman we saw hire Healy. Looki slightly younger with a graduation cap and tassel... OUT THE WINDOW: The GENUINE ARTICLE. No mistaking her. Blue-Face just won the lottery. Everything changes, that quick. Holly, now worthless. Blue-Face lunges ACROSS her. Thrusts open the DOOR, pinning Holly in the process.

dialogues.speaker: BLUE-FACE
dialogues.text: Don't fucking move.  56

dialogues.speaker: A GUN MATERIALIZES
dialogues.text: In his outstretched fist. He sights down the barrel. This is it, he's not fucking around. And you know what..? Holly decides she isn't either. Fuck being scared. She wrenches one arm free--

dialogues.speaker: GRABS THE DOOR AND YANKS IT SHUT
dialogues.text: Right on Blue-Face's wrist. A loud CRUNCH--! He BARKS sudden PAIN. The gun bucks in his hand. DISCHARGES, KA-POW--! Shot goes wild. Blasts splinters from the valet box. BLUE FACE recoils and HOLLY kicks the door back open. Leaping from the car--

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Amelia, run!! Amelia SPINS. Locks eyes with Holly... BOLTS like a cheet PANIC. People yelling, rushing for cover. Holly stumbles, gains her feet as Blue-Face fumbles with the gun, reachin for her-- This time she slams the door ON HIS FINGER. PAIN, white-hot. He shrieks, falls back inside the car. Holly doesn't miss a beat-- SHE RUNS FOR IT. Heart thudding, feet slapping pavement. Chasing a blotch of retreating YELLOW, as Amelia flees do the canyon. The party's become a ROUT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARCH heading up the STAIRS fast-- following the sound of the GUNSHOT. The wood, vibrating... thrumming. He looks u

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Fuck me. Panicked PARTY GUESTS. STAMPEDING DOWN towards him, as be him they STAMPEDE UP. He fights through, bursts out--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onto the drive. Casts about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 57 BLUE-FACE at the wheel. Laying rubber. People actually FL themselves aside-! IT SCREECHES off, down the canyon. March turns -- the VALET who parked his car earlier gives him a slightly surprised look:

dialogues.speaker: VALET
dialogues.text: Hey, man, I think that limo is going after the girl who was in your trunk! Far out, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: My trunk--? (realizing) Oh, fuck. FUCK..! (beat) Where the hell are my keys?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DECK, now empty after the exodus. HEALY and OLDER GUY. Still at it. Circling each other. OLDER GUY darts in quickly, brandishing the knife. HEALY scrambles back -- Stumbles against the HOT TUB. A glint of METAL in the water. THE GUN. Healy dodges a SLASH -- DIVES for the weapon. Comes up, soaking wet, spins to FIRE -- Too late. Because OLDER GUY'S already ON TOP OF HIM. Tackles him. STABBING. As they both PITCH BACKWARD -- Over the EMBANKMENT. Tumbling, bouncing. DOWN THE WOODED HILLSIDE. Skipping, end over end. Kicking up dirt -- Then WHAM--! WHAM--! the two men slam to an abrupt STOP i the middle of a clearing. Twenty yards apart. Healy groggy, bleeding, wet... The REVOLVER'S GONE. He spots it to his left. Tries to stand. Collapses. SCRAMBLES for the gun. Hands and knees. Snatches it up and AIMS IT before Older Guy can even get his feet. PULLS THE TRIGGER: CLICK--! Older Guy FLINCHES -- Nothing. It's a misfire. Healy pulls the trigger twice more --  58

dialogues.speaker: CLICK--
dialogues.text: It won't fire. He gets it immediately: The cartridges are Older Guy smiles. He's still got the knife. He starts for Healy. Oh, Shit. Frantically, Healy flips the GUN CYLINDER open. Spins it as fast as he can. Water flying off the thing. Flicks it back into place. Aims. Older Guy ten yards away

dialogues.speaker: CLICK--
dialogues.text: Fuck. Healy tries to stand and back up at the same time. Falls again. Fuck. Flicks the cylinder open. Spins it. Desperate. Blows on it this time-- Older Guy is almost on him. He flicks the cylinder closed

dialogues.speaker: CLICK--
dialogues.text: Older Guy SWINGS THE KNIFE--

dialogues.speaker: CLICK--
dialogues.text: MUZZLE FLASH. Close range. The bullet catches Older Guy i the collar bone. SHATTERS IT. Blood and flesh go flying. Older Guy SCREAMS, spun like a top. Goes down flailing. The shot echoes in the canyon closeness. HEALY drops his arm to his side. Chest heaving. There. Much better. Tosses the gun. Spits blood. Steels himself. Staggers to his feet. Half-limping now. Kicks the knife away. Looms over Older Guy.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GUY
dialogues.text: (wheezing) Wait... You don't... I can pay you. I can pay y-- Healy rears back and STOMPS the guy's elbow. We hear a SHARP SNAP and the man SCREAMS again. SQUIRMING

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Are you bargaining with me? Older Guy shakes his head emphatically.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GUY
dialogues.text: No... No... I'm gone... You'll never... see me again... Never...  59 Healy takes the KNIFE. Holds it an INCH from the guy's EY

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. Where will you be?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER GUY
dialogues.text: Mi... Michigan... Healy considers a beat. Then, surprisingly, nods.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Michigan works. Withdraws the knife. Staggers upright. Was it worth it? He'll worry about that later. Turns, starts uphill -- the just as suddenly STOPS. Ears pricked: A SCREECH OF TIRES from down the canyon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can see A ROAD below us, through the trees. Healy spots two figures RUNNING. They dodge across the tarmac. Start down a wooded SLOPE. Getting OFF THE ROAD. Behind them, A LIMO SHRIEKS TO A STOP. A MAN jumps out, pulling a gun. Hard to say from this distance, but it looks like his face might be BLUE. Healy galvanizes. Powers forward. Running on his hurt leg Older Guy, forgotten -- and meanwhile

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a corner full-speed. UP AHEAD-- THE LIMO. Angled in the middle of the road. BLUE-FACE aiming a gun down the canyon. FIRING. No hesitation. March VEERS. Targeting Blue-Face. Stomps the accelerator. Engine, howling..! BLUE-FACE reacts to the noise. Doesn't miss a beat. Spins and FIRES RIGHT AT MARCH. WINDSHIELD, splintered..! March ducks. SKIDDING. OUT OF CONTROL. Blue-Face DIVES aside, nick of time, as MARCH'S CAR - Fishtails. Slews off the road...  60 Just misses a full-grown DEER. Sends it SCAMPERING. A TREE RUSHES AT US. March slams it HEAD ON... WHAM--! Silence. A beat. March shakes his head. Clearing it. Turn BLUE-FACE is gone. Down the hillside. March blinks, and then-- Someone ELSE flashes across the road, limping:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Healy doesn't stop. Hobbles, yelling back, pointing:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: See if you can cut him off! Go! Shit. March jams it in reverse. Pulling free. Takes off a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holly and Amelia stumble down onto another paved road. Am clutching her BACKPACK. Both running for their lives--

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Go! Run! What happens next happens quickly:

dialogues.speaker: BLUE-FACE
dialogues.text: Emerges from the trees behind them. Stops, drawing a bead Amelia. His finger tenses on the trigger, as

dialogues.speaker: A DEER BURSTS FROM COVER
dialogues.text: Ten feet away. Leaping into the road. It's the one that March spooked. It fetches up sharply, seeing Blue-Face -- At which point, inexplicably, we make a HARD CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: THE INTERIOR OF A FAMILY SEDAN
dialogues.text: DAD, driving a tad fast, whips around a corner. From the back seat, his son YELLS:

dialogues.speaker: DEER
dialogues.text: Dad cries out, SWERVES--! Misses the deer, thank God. Hits BLUE-FACE instead.  61 Just fucking nails him--! FLINGS him, limbs skewed, into air... He lands with a sickening THUD--! CUT TO: HOLLY -- Still running. Shoots a look back. Sees the CAR come to a SKITTERING STOP. Sees THE DAD get out... Stare Then HOP BACK in his car and take off. Leaving BLUE-FACE lying there, in the middle of the road. His leg, twisted back at an impossible angle... Holly stops... Hesitates...

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: What the hell are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: He's HURT. Just... just hang on! She starts back toward him. Amelia calling after her:

dialogues.speaker: AMELIA
dialogues.text: Are you crazy?! Stay away from him! Holly just keeps going. Onto the road. Approaches the downed man-- He's a mess. He rolls over, gasping... SEES HOLLY. Stops. Holly stares back at him... Turns to call to Amelia -- Sees her RETREATING at a dead run. Goodbye. BLUE-FACE, meanwhile, is out of it... He reaches out a ha for her... She makes a decision. Crouches, takes his hand

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: It's okay... you're gonna be alright... I'll get help. A RUSTLING sound. Holly spins, startled-- HEALY is standing behind her. Staring down at BLUE-FACE.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: A car hit him, we need an ambulance..!

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Right. He strips off his sliced up jacket, lays it across Blue-F

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Holly, go flag someone down... Hurry, he's in a bad way. Holly scurries off. Healy and Blue-Face, alone now.  62 He looms over the prone figure. For a moment, Blue-Face turns his eyes upward at Healy, imploring -- then, with dawning recognition:

dialogues.speaker: BLUE-FACE
dialogues.text: You... Healy regards him, detached.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Me. Blue Face coughs... Fixes Healy with a belligerent grin:

dialogues.speaker: BLUE-FACE
dialogues.text: Too late... The word already went out on you and the private cop... Ever hear... of John Boy..? By now, he's... heard of you... You ain't got long to live. Healy shrugs philosophically.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Nobody does. He reaches out a powerful hand; calmly, clinically...

dialogues.speaker: QUICK TIME CUT
dialogues.text: HOLLY comes running back down the road. Desperate, fluste

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Healy! No one's stopping! Healy stands over BLUE-FACE'S BODY. Slipping his jacket back on:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Sorry... He didn't make it. Holly shifts her gaze to the corpse. Stunned. Casually, Healy leans down, starts rifling the dead man's clothing. Comes up with a WALLET. Checks the license: Seymour Jones. Detroit, Michigan. He frowns at that... Just as HEADLIGHTS SWEEP them. Healy quickly tosses the wallet, as RED AND BLUE flashers fill the night --

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: And that would be the cops.  63 Holly doesn't even look up. She can't stop staring at the body in the road. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POLICE CARS, skewed across the roadway. A COP routes traffic, past the accident site -- BLUE FACE'S BODY is loaded into an ambulance.

dialogues.speaker: PARKED AT ROADSIDE
dialogues.text: Healy leans against it, calmly smoking. While March argue the UNIFORMED OFFICER, standing guard:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Look, you got our statements. Can I talk to my kid now or what? She's over with the nurse.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Sir, I was told to keep you here. So I'm keeping you here. Just following orders.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: (indignant) Yeah, well... Hitler was just following orders! Healy thinks about correcting March -- but really, what's point..? Right then, a WOMAN appears at the cop's side. She's dark. Dark hair. Dark eyes. And beautiful. Late 20s early 30s. She wears a crisp, tailored business suit. As soon as she arrives, the cop gives her a quick nod and departs. Just like that... The woman smiles at March:

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: You're Mr. March, I think. (to Healy) And you are..?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Not answering that question.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN / TALLY
dialogues.text: (slight shrug) My name is Tally. If you'll come with me..? My boss would like a word. March and Healy just exchange looks. Follow warily, as sh leads them to a black SEDAN. Stops, waits, as --

dialogues.speaker: THE BACK WINDOW GLIDES DOWN
dialogues.text: 64 Revealing ANOTHER WOMAN. Late 40's. Well kept.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: Gentlemen. How do you do?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: About this bad, most of the time.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: My name is Judith Kuttner. I work for the California Department of Justice.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I see... Well, that explains exactly nothing. What the hell's all this about? Why are you holding us?

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: Please, keep your voice down. I'm trying to be discrete here... (pause, deep breath) I'm Amelia's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: L.A. continues to dazzle. Clouds awash with the glitter f below. TALLY plays a game with HOLLY in the background. A

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER AND OUR GUYS
dialogues.text: Sit at a picnic table. Talking. The SEDAN shields them fr the road. Kuttner nervously lights a smoke... There's a snapshot of Amelia on the table.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: First off, I want to thank you. From the interviews we're getting, it sounds like you might have saved my daughter's life.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: That was mostly Holly. Kuttner glances back at Holly. Chews her lip. Thinking...

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: I need your help. And I'm wondering if I can really trust you.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Most people don't... But I'm starting to get the idea you don't have much of a choice. Kuttner regards March... Makes a decision.  65

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: My situation is... well, "delicate" is putting it mildly. My job can be very public sometimes -- Healy frowns -- then suddenly snaps his fingers:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: That's where I've seen you before -- on TV. Prosecuting that car company thing.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: The lawsuit over the catalytic converter. Exactly. That's half my day. (beat) The other half I spend on pornography.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Really..? That makes two of us.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: You may have noticed that Hollywood Boulevard has devolved into a cesspool. Not to give cesspools a bad name.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: So you're, like, an anti-porn crusader?

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: More or less... The Vegas mob is looking to expand their porn apparatus to L.A. I'm doing everything I can to stop that--

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Right. Porn is bad, yes, we get it -- (breaks off, squints) -- Wait... Your daughter made a Sid Shattuck film. Kuttner nods. Stares off:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Ouch... Ma'am, no offense -- but why'd Amelia do this film, if she knew it could embarrass you?

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: Oh, that's what she wanted. She's a petulant child, she... lashed out. Since her father died we've had... a difficult relationship.  She stubs 66

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: So, there's a film out there, somewhere. A prime piece of blackmail.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: That would be my worry, except for one small detail -- (beat) There is no film. Not anymore. out her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: It's been destroyed... There was a fire, Amelia's friend, boyfriend, whatever he was--

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Dean. Yeah. We've been to the house.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: This Dean was apparently editing the film when the fire started -- all the footage burned. Everything.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: A great loss to cinema, I'm sure. That begs the question: (beat) Mrs. Kuttner, why is everyone who worked on that film now dying?

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: I don't know, Mr. March. I wish I did. All I know is Amelia is in danger.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: So put her in protective custody. After tonight she'll get scared, come running home--

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: No. She won't. You don't understand-- (sudden tears) I know how she thinks. She doesn't trust me. I'm... Big Brother. I'm the government. (beat) She thinks it's me doing all this. The implications of this set in. She wipes her eyes.  67

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: My daughter is out there, running scared. And she can't call home... because she thinks her own mother is trying to kill her. She reaches into her bag. Takes out a CHECKBOOK.

dialogues.speaker: KUTTNER
dialogues.text: I want to hire you. Both of you. Find Amelia. Protect her.

dialogues.speaker: CHECKBOOK
dialogues.text: We see the sum take shape -- T-E-N THOUSA--

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Hire us? Sure. But we don't come cheap. (smug) I'm thinking five thousand dollars. She stops writing. Pause... She rips up the check. Starts writing again. March grins triumphantly at Healy. CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy stands back here. Staring at the half empty pool. Smoking... March comes out through the sliding glass door

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: She's asleep now. She's fine. Healy nods. March kicks a beachball into the pool.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Listen, something bothers me... (frowns ) Kuttner's prosecuting this car company thing, right? Could mean hundreds of millions against the big three.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Yeah. So?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: That guy tonight, the Blue-face one... Got a look at his ID. (beat) He's from Detroit.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: ... Probably nothing. Healy nods... Then:  68

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Oh, I almost forgot... He reaches into his coat. Takes out the COW-SHAPED paper found at the party.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I found this in Shattuck's office. (reads ) 28-10 Burbank Apt. Western, Flight 2. 10:30 pm... I think Amelia wrote this. March glances at it: 28-10 BURBANK APT. WEST, FLT 2, 10:3

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: She might be trying to skip town -- what do you think? March shakes his head, a beat --

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: I think whatever it is, it can wait. I need 8 hours... (beat) Just drop by in the afternoon tomorrow. We'll sort it all out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy, driving away from March's house. He spots somethin out the side window, squints:

dialogues.speaker: BEHIND SOME CONSTRUCTION FENCING
dialogues.text: We can just make out the beam of a FLASHLIGHT -- held by small figure sitting in the dirt... Reading from a book. Healy, bewildered. He hits the brakes and we CUT TO:

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY MARCH
dialogues.text: Sitting Indian style in the middle of the vacant lot -- t exactly where we first met her... She reads out loud to n Healy steps into frame behind Her... She stops reading bu doesn't look up:

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Hey. Healy glances around. No one else here.  69

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You've got your foot in the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: ~.. What?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: (turns) Your foot. It's in the toilet.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Oh. Healy takes a couple of steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You just knocked over the lamp.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Right. Sorry... Was this your room?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: «+. No. Mom and Dad's. Healy nods: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: «++. Mom loved detective stories. She closes the book. Takes a deep lungful of night air.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Aren't you supposed to be in bed?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I see. (nods ) ... Then I'll leave you to it. Healy turns to leave... Heads back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Mr. Healy..? Can I ask you something? Healy stops, looks back:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: ... What did you do to that man tonight?  70

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: What. .?

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: On the road... When I went to go get help. What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: I... Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: You didn't... (pause) .».. Did you kill him?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: No... Of course not. I -- of course not. She studies him a moment longer. Finally nods: she believ

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: Okay... That's good... (little smile) ... I knew you couldn't do something like that... Goodnight, Mr. Healy.

dialogues.speaker: A CAR DOOR SLAMMING
dialogues.text: As Healy gets back into his car. Keys the ignition. Catches sight of himself in the rearview mirror: Notices something he hadn't before... Something troubling He shakes it off -- Puts the car in gear. Drives away... And we CUT TO BLACK. Darkness. Silence. A count of FOUR, FADE UP. A TV NEWSCAST. A SLICK, WELL DRESSED MAN being interviewed. As workers in the background set up tables.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER
dialogues.text: I'm here with a representative of the Detroit Auto Manufacturers, Mr. Bergen Paulsen... Mr. Paulsen, I understand you're in town today getting ready for the Auto show--

dialogues.speaker: PAULSEN
dialogues.text: That's right, Mike. For thirty years, it's been my privilege to debut the finest in automotive technology. Right here in L.A. The CAMERA starts to pull back from the TV set now.  71 We're inside Healy's apartment. The TV drones on, unnotic The reporter asking about the catalytic converter lawsuit Healy walks past frame. Fresh from the shower. Hair tousl We follow him over to his "word of the day" calendar: Internecine \In.ter.ne.cine\, adj: Pertaining to dissenti within a group; mutually destructive. He ponders a moment, then says out loud:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: The marriage failed when their internecine struggle overwhelmed what love remained. He smiles, satisfied. Shrugs on his coat. Exits whistling

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Healy sits on the front porch. Waiting. Smoking. MARCH'S CAR pulls into the driveway. March and Holly clim out. She's carrying packages. March carries a new suit.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Hey, hey! The man of the hour! They approach Healy.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Didn't know what time you'd be here. You said the afternoon--

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Right. Sure. Sorry... But I went to the bank. Got your money. Right here. He pulls out an envelope.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: That's all of it. Half. Twenty-five hundred... Yep... (beat) You know, minus a couple hundred... Damage to the car... I figured you'd want to chip in for that. Healy just shrugs it off.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Sure.  72

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: What do you think..? March holds up his suit, proudly. It's maroon.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Nice... I guess. Holly pushes past Healy. She does not look happy.

dialogues.speaker: HOLLY
dialogues.text: We stopped at a bar. That's why we're late. She darts inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Right... So, uh, how you wanna do this?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Well... I think we, you know, give it a couple of days... Then we'll call Kuttner, see if we can hit her up for a second installment.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: We can -- I mean... What..?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: You don't want to call too soon. Gotta act like you're on to something, been working hard... Then wammo. (beat) I'm good at this. Trust me. He heads into the house. Healy turns, follows him inside:

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Wait, you're just gonna... lie to her?

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Yeah. (off Healy's expression) What?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: She paid us. ME. She paid me to do a job... I don't wanna lie to her.

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Fine. I'll lie to her. (beat) Don't worry. This is a good thing. We're gonna get some free bread.  73 March hits play on his answering machine. He's got two messages. Both from Lily Glenn, Misty's aunt: LILY (on machine) Mr. March, this is Lily Glenn. I haven't heard from you about Misty's case-- March fast forwards it: LILY (on machine) Mr. March, I really want to find out if you've made progress-- March deletes both messages. Uninterested... Looks up:

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Right. So, we good?

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Good..? No, we're not good. (beat) Look, we have theses clues to follow -- He fishes out the COW-SHAPED PAPER he got off Blue Face.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
dialogues.text: Burbank Airport? Western flight 2? I'm thinking she's skipping town --

dialogues.speaker: MARCH
dialogues.text: Great! Fine! She gets shot in another city. We're off the hook. Healy turns, starts to walk back out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: HEALY
